{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3125826,"name":"seg9585","username":"seg9585","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/seg9585/{size}/1974_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-14T02:30:13.346Z","cooked":"

My team’s design is calling for some relatively longer extruded aluminum arms to maximize horizontal reach and I’m trying to decide which alloy is right for this particular application.
I generally buy 6061 for most general purpose structural applications but switch to 6063 where the design needs some more precise machining. I’ve been considering using 7075 or 2024 for this particular application for additional strength and stiffness but I’m concerned they could be more brittle/shatter rather than bend if we ended up in a higher impact situation (wall, other robots, Rt ).

Do any other teams have practical FRC experience with these alloys and their performance on the field for long extrusion arms?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2023-01-14T02:30:13.346Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":205,"reads":322,"readers_count":321,"score":1094.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":423030,"topic_slug":"aluminum-alloy-for-longer-extruded-arms","display_username":"seg9585","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6078,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/aluminum-alloy-for-longer-extruded-arms/423030/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3125827,"name":"R.C.","username":"R.C","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/r.c/{size}/264998_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-14T02:31:45.577Z","cooked":"

Its easier to go 6061 but move to a larger OD tube.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2023-01-14T02:31:45.577Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":319,"readers_count":318,"score":218.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":423030,"topic_slug":"aluminum-alloy-for-longer-extruded-arms","display_username":"R.C.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":10}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9979,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/aluminum-alloy-for-longer-extruded-arms/423030/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":10},{"id":"thinking","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":11,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3125831,"name":"Troy Dietz","username":"troy_dietz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/troy_dietz/{size}/135768_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-14T02:34:38.317Z","cooked":"
seg9585:

but switch to 6063 where the design needs some more precise machining.

image700×394 39.8 KB

Generally, if your arm design doesn’t work in 6061, it’s also not going to work in 7075 (and it will very not work in 6063). Difficulty in machining 7075 is usually more of a problem rather than being brittle compared to 6061 in the finished product.
A brittle vs ductile failure in FRC doesn’t matter too much (though the resilience of the material does, of course), as the solution for both is either replace the part or rivet gussets over the broken area.

FYI, the choice of alloy makes no difference in stiffness.

Larger OD tube increases weight for a given length, not to mention volumetric considerations

2024 has a higher yield strength and higher modulus of elasticity than 6061. Try putting different alloys in a metal bender and say there’s no difference…

I’m comparing the options specifically for aluminum here. I didn’t say I was counting out polycarb or wood or 3D printing or whatever other materials you particularly prefer

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2023-01-14T02:50:01.294Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":236,"readers_count":235,"score":47.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":423030,"topic_slug":"aluminum-alloy-for-longer-extruded-arms","display_username":"seg9585","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":3300,"username":"Gdeaver","name":"Gdeaver","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/2acd7d/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6078,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/aluminum-alloy-for-longer-extruded-arms/423030/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3125877,"name":"Andrew Lawrence","username":"Andrew_L","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/andrew_l/{size}/270442_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-14T03:01:07.425Z","cooked":"

Use 6061, don’t think too hard about it. 254 has used it for mechanisms for years and beat us all with it.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2023-01-14T03:01:07.425Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":216,"readers_count":215,"score":123.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":423030,"topic_slug":"aluminum-alloy-for-longer-extruded-arms","display_username":"Andrew Lawrence","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28413,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Yo! Champ in the making!"},"post_url":"/t/aluminum-alloy-for-longer-extruded-arms/423030/9","custom_user_title":"Yo! Champ in the making!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3125899,"name":"seg9585","username":"seg9585","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/seg9585/{size}/1974_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-14T03:26:57.211Z","cooked":"

I’m surprised with the amount of snark on this thread in general (not your post specifically). Maybe I need to back up and reword this a little bit.
My team has a very limited budget to buy new aluminum extrusion, but I found an aerospace machinist sponsor who is donating a lot of rems to the team and most of what they have is 7075, 2024, and titanium alloys. I was trying to approach this from a team experience/analysis standpoint rather than “take whatever I can get” in order to help justify material usage. 2024 has performed significantly better in my experience in some climbing arms in past games. We are building practice parts in rems material but I can justify buying 6061/6063 if the performance of the other alloys is worse in this application

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2023-01-14T03:26:57.387Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":192,"readers_count":191,"score":48.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":423030,"topic_slug":"aluminum-alloy-for-longer-extruded-arms","display_username":"seg9585","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28413,"username":"Andrew_L","name":"Andrew Lawrence","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/andrew_l/{size}/270442_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6078,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":"Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.","can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/aluminum-alloy-for-longer-extruded-arms/423030/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3125931,"name":"Ari Meles-Braverman","username":"AriMB","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arimb/{size}/189989_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-14T04:01:01.829Z","cooked":"

“I have this material and want to know if it will work” and “I want to buy this hard to get material because I think it will give me an advantage” are two different questions with different considerations. I don’t think anyone here is suggesting 2024 or 7075 extrusions will be noticeably worse in an FRC context than the standard 6061. But for most teams they’re a lot harder to get their hands on and not worth the trouble. If you have access to them for free from a sponsor though, you might as well take advantage of that instead of paying extra for 6061.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2023-01-14T04:01:01.829Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":161,"readers_count":160,"score":82.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":423030,"topic_slug":"aluminum-alloy-for-longer-extruded-arms","display_username":"Ari Meles-Braverman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":6078,"username":"seg9585","name":"seg9585","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/seg9585/{size}/1974_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25012,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/aluminum-alloy-for-longer-extruded-arms/423030/11","custom_user_title":"FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3125934,"name":"R.C.","username":"R.C","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/r.c/{size}/264998_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-14T04:04:58.003Z","cooked":"

I’m genuinely trying to be helpful. In 2011 (big arm robot) and other years we’ve used large diameter thin wall tubed with the best results.

Without knowing your setup, constraints and other limitations its hard to make greyt suggestions. But if I was making an arm this year I’d do 2x2x.060" square or 2" round tube. You can also play with .030" , .040" and .050" thin wall tube if you want weight reduction. The material choice will do some but your main gains will come from setup, shape and diameter of said joint/arm.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2023-01-14T04:04:58.003Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":150,"readers_count":149,"score":60.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":423030,"topic_slug":"aluminum-alloy-for-longer-extruded-arms","display_username":"R.C.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":6078,"username":"seg9585","name":"seg9585","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/seg9585/{size}/1974_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9979,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/aluminum-alloy-for-longer-extruded-arms/423030/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3125941,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-14T04:14:42.735Z","cooked":"

Yes, 2024 and 7075 will give you a higher yield. In general they are not as readily available as 6061 or 6063 extrusion. I’m only seeing bars, plates, strips, and angles in 7075 on McMaster. If you’ve got useful shapes then go for it! They both machine very well. Better than 6063 for sure; that stuff is kind of gummy! Bends nice, though!

The difference in elastic modulus is very small; if you want to change stiffness you either need to change dimensions or completely change the material. IE, go to steel.

Strength is a squared function of the characteristic dimension of the extrusion, so a little bigger yields a lot more strength.

Stiffness is cubed. So, LOTS more improvement for a step up in size.

Right, and my initial question was trying to avoid taking the “is it good enough?” Approach while attempting to understand the real world experience others may have had with these materials in order to feed into my MBSE trade study process. I consider TRL to be a pretty important input for design verification, so in this realm it deals with previous design experiences. When I reach the implementation stage of my model I will most definitely consider which materials are both accessible and meet the design requirements, but we aren’t there yet

Thanks! I’ve had similar experience with 6063 gumminess to the point where it’s use has been restricted in some sponsor’s CNC machines, and have also experienced 7075 aluminum plates “snapping” in an FRC application due to its brittle nature. Most of what I’ve found in the 2024 and 7075 realm is round tubing, which is one example of tubing made available to me:

Buy Specialty Aluminum Online

The difference in elastic modulus is about 5%, so no you can not feel that difference. In similar tempers (T6 for example) the 2024 alloy does have a 25% greater yield strength and you probably would feel that.
